topic.title: Running Applets without a Web Browser

keywords.keyword: Running Applets without a Web Browser

para.text: Running Applets without a Web Browser

para.style: text-align:left; text-indent:0px; margin-top:14px; margin-right:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; line-height:1.46; background-color:transparent; white-space:normal; page-break-inside:auto; page-break-after:auto; border:none; tabstops:none;

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: So far, we have been concerned with deploying applets to binary packages which can then be loaded and run in a web browser by the Dolphin
. However, this is by no means the only way to run these applets. It is quite possible to write a Dolphin application that is capable of instantiating classes loaded dynamically from binary packages.

para.style: text-align:left; text-indent:0px; margin-top:14px; margin-right:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; line-height:1.46; background-color:transparent; white-space:normal; page-break-inside:auto; page-break-after:auto; border:none; tabstops:none;

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: In order to do this, your application must have the

package installed since the loading mechanism makes use of some of the classes supplied with it. The best way to illustrate procedure is probably by example. We will assume that you have already deployed the Hello World Applet package to a binary .PAK file.
